selected_quotes: #Chromatin organization into higher-order structures generates torsional stress can lead to DNA breaks
Genome organization drives chromosome fragility Translocation breakpoints... are enriched at…
To understand genomic fragility, a key underpinning of #cancer, we need to know #3D and topology of the genome
Genome Organization drives #ChromosoneFragility TopologicalStress relief AndreNussenzweig
Stunning work by Nussenzweig and colleagues of

citation.abstract: In this study, we show that evolutionarily conserved chromosome loop anchors bound by CCCTC-binding factor (CTCF) and cohesin are vulnerable to DNA double strand breaks (DSBs) mediated by topoisomerase 2B (TOP2B). Polymorphisms in the genome that redistribute CTCF/cohesin occupancy rewire DNA cleavage sites to novel loop anchors. While transcription- and replication-coupled genomic rearrangements have been well documented, we demonstrate that DSBs formed at loop anchors are largely transcription-, replication-, and cell-type-independent. DSBs are continuously formed throughout interphase, are enriched on both sides of strong topological domain borders, and frequently occur at breakpoint clusters commonly translocated in cancer. Thus, loop anchors serve as fragile sites that generate DSBs and chromosomal rearrangements.
citation.title: Genome Organization Drives Chromosome Fragility

facebook.title: Genome Organization Drives Chromosome Fragility
facebook.summary: Chromatin assembly into higher-order structures generates torsional stress that makes chromosome loop anchor regions more vulnerable to topoisomerase 2-mediated DNA breaks.

facebook.summary: The genome is organized into many loops and 3D structures. In the current issue of Cell, a new study shows that these loop anchor regions are vulnerable to double-stranded DNA breaks due to torsional stress on the DNA, and these breaks can lead to chromoso
